summary: Mucinous tumors are a type of ovarian tumor, accounting for approximately 36% of all ovarian neoplasms. They are characterized by being filled with a mucus-like material produced by mucus-secreting goblet cells. Approximately 75% are benign, 10% are borderline, and 15% are malignant. They can become very large and may present bilaterally, though this is rare for primary tumors.
causes: Malignancy may be focally present in mucinous neoplasms of the ovary
risk_factors: Smoking (current smokers: relative risk 2.22, past smokers: relative risk 2.02)
symptoms: Papillae and solid areas (in borderline and malignant tumors)
diagnosis: Differentiation of borderline tumors from malignant tumors based on clear stromal invasion
Assessment for cellular atypia and stratification
Evaluation of loss of normal tissue architecture
Imaging (implied for assessing organ involvement and bilaterality)
